awd_titl_txt: Interactions of Transition Metal Ions with RNA: Structure and Function
awd_abstract_narration:
The Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division funds this award. Professor Victoria J. DeRose from the University of Oregon investigates the structures of complex ribonucleic acid (RNA) biopolymers. RNA takes part in a wide variety of life sustaining processes. It adopts complex and dynamic structures that are challenging to monitor and predict with current methods. In this research, new platinum compounds are developed as RNA structure probes and used to determine RNA structures in cells. The outcomes of this project are novel methods and reagents for RNA structure analysis, and new information about large RNA structures in cells. The breadth of methods applied to this project supports a unique interdisciplinary training environment for workforce development, including summer undergraduate training for women and other underrepresented groups in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM). 

The goals of this research are to develop methods for long-range tertiary interactions in large RNAs and to understand determinants for targeting compounds to complex RNA structures. The project develops exchange-inert platinum (Pt(II)) complexes as RNA crosslinking reagents and incorporates them into approaches for RNA structure determination. Pt(II) compounds crosslink purine-rich but noncanonical regions in RNA such as internal loops and junctions and are robust through RNA isolation methods. To enable crosslink analysis, novel modified Pt(II) click reagents are synthesized with installed handles for selective post-treatment modification of Pt(II) RNA species. Structure analysis protocols based on the unique chemistry of these Pt(II) complexes and high-throughput sequencing methods are developed, along with methods to directly image crosslinked species. The specificity of small-molecule RNA interactions is probed through design of enhanced Pt ligands. These approaches are used to predict structures of RNAs in vitro and in-cell, including tertiary structures in long non-coding RNAs.

por.por_cntn:
Metal ions have unique chemical interactions in biological systems. An overarching goal of this project is to understand the interactions of small metal complexes with nucleic acids and other biomolecules in cells, and to use these interactions to gain information about biomolecular structure and function. Square-planar Pt(II) compounds form long-lived crosslinks with nucleic acids that can perturb biomolecular function, and also provide a tool for identifying complexities of nucleic acid structures. Being able to isolate and identify Pt-bound species is one important goal in being able to study Pt-biomolecule interactions. In one research direction, new ways to isolate Pt-bound nucleic acids from cells were demonstrated using novel platinum compounds modified to perform azide-alkyne cycloaddition ?click? chemistry. DNA or proteins bound to click-enabled Pt compounds were conjugated to biotin-modified oligonucleotides and isolated using biotin-streptavidin pulldown. It was found that Pt(II)-bound proteins crosslinked with oligonucleotides even in the absence of the click reaction, providing an additional mode of isolating Pt-protein-nucleic acid complexes. Progress was also made towards developing new Pt(II) compounds modified for copper-free cyclopropene-tetrazine ligation, which would enable detection of Pt localization in living cells. During the course of this project, new results in the field revealed that certain Pt(II) compounds were able to specifically interfere with nucleolar processes, causing cell death by nucleolar stress pathways. The nucleolus is a membraneless compartment where ribosomes are synthesized, which a process critical to cell function. It is not understood how the ligands of Pt(II) compounds might direct them to target the nucleolus rather than cause the canonical DNA damage response previously thought to be common for cell death induced by Pt(II) compounds. To establish the influence of Pt(II) ligand sphere on nucleolar processes, a cell-imaging assay and analysis pipeline was developed for quantifying nucleolar stress, and structure-function studies employed to discover ligand properties specific to the ability of Pt(II) compounds to influence the nucleolus. Based on this work, it was found that nucleolar stress induction depends sensitively on the size and modifications of diaminocyclohexane Pt(II) ligands, and that nucleolar stress is accompanied by distinct inhibition of RNA Polymerase I, which is responsible for synthesizing the RNA component of ribosomes. These studies establish certain Pt(II) compounds as a new class of nucleolar inhibitors, which impacts the fields of bioinorganic chemistry, nucleic acid chemistry, and nucleolar biology. This work was disseminated in published journal articles and reviews, graduate student PhD and undergraduate Honors theses, and talks at Universities and national and international meetings. 

 A major outcome of this project is the training of students in interdisciplinary research areas including chemical synthesis, bioanalytical methods, and cell and molecular biology. This broad training equips trainees with skills that support success in a variety of future careers. Over this project period, eleven graduate and four undergraduate students participated in aspects of the work, as well as one postdoctoral researcher who is now employed in biotechnology. Three students obtained PhDs during this period; one is an academic postdoctoral researcher, one is employed in a biotechnology company, and one is entering science education. Of the four undergraduate students, one is entering an MD-PhD program, one is employed in biotechnology, and two were visiting summer REU students continuing their undergraduate degrees. Eleven of the fifteen students trained during this period are women and four are members of other groups underrepresented in STEM. All graduate student participants obtained significant mentoring experience, and all participants gave research presentations in either local or national research meeting venues.
